abstracts.cdata!:
The Health Sector Reform Project for
            Jordan had the following ratings: the outcome was
            satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was modest, and the Bank
            and borrower performance were both satisfactory. The lessons
            learned indicate that an institutional capacity assessment
            of this project would have identified key constraints which
            could have been used to strengthen project design, and
            identified more realistic outcome indicators to more
            objectively measure achievements. The Bank should be more
            realistic in what can actually be achieved within a single
            investment operation. As with previous projects, once
            monitoring indicators have been agreed to during project
            preparation, resources should be dedicated to collecting all
            baseline data. It is important to assess Government
            commitment to reform initiatives based on clear commitment
            from both the MOP as well as the sectoral ministry
            responsible for implementation and not solely from the MOP.
            For activities that require ongoing financial and other
            resources after the project closes, dialogue on
            sustainability arrangements need to be held and agreements
            incorporated in the project appraisal document during
            preparation. Closer attention should have been paid to
            implementing the QAG quality-at-entry (QAE) assessment
            recommendations of this project which were crucial to
            implementation success. In relation to the previous
            recommendation and for all projects in general, QAE
            assessments should be more dynamic rather than being mainly
            treated as a standard Bank requirement. In terms of future
            support of the health sector in Jordan, the Bank needs to be
            more selective in the areas it chooses to support, focusing
            on activities where the Bank has a comparative advantage.

5084119.trustfund:
TF034527-JORDAN - HEALTH SECTOR REFORM,TF022213-CANADIAN GENERAL CTF II-EGYPT,TF029400-PHRD - HEALTH CARE FINANCING
            AND DELIVERY PROJECT,TF033689-MENA REGION - EDUCATION,TF029350-PHRD-HEALTH CARE FINANCING
            & DELIVERY PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The Government of Jordan is taking
            actions for a long-term reform program in the health sector.
            Placed within the strategic context, the program will
            contribute to the achievement of macroeconomic stability and
            growth. The Health Sector Reform Project supports the first
            phase of the reform program, and its main objectives are to
            contain growth in health expenditures, improve health care
            services, and assure efficiency in the use of physical
            facilities. The project components include: 1) The
            rationalization of the investment strategy for health
            delivery systems, which will directly support economic
            efficiency improvement. A health facility masterplan will
            incorporate norms and standards, overall needs, and public
            and private sector capacity. 2) The development of health
            information systems, which will provide relevant and timely
            epidemiological data and improve management information
            systems for patients record keeping, services, inventory,
            and personnel. 3) The improvement of private hospital
            financing will establish accounting standards and adjust
            budgetary allocations efficiently. 4) The reform of the
            pharmaceutical sector will promote generic substitution,
            rationalize the use of drugs, and reform drug procurement.
            5) A continuing reform process will be addressed, and
            special studies conducted. Technical expertise recruits will
            aim at exploring alternative reform proposals.
